Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Hey, uh, can I help you out in here?

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Oh, I'm all set, thanks.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Gotcha. Good. I'd go with the rows. That's a good idea.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Today is diversity day and someone's going to come in and talk to us about diversity. It's something that I've been pushing, that I've been wanting to push, for a long time and Corporate mandated it. And I never actually talked to Corporate about it. They kind of beat me to the punch, the bastards. But I was going to. And I think it's very important that we have this. I'm very, very excited.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: That's the thing. It's very sturdy paper and on the back it says, "100% post-consumer content." What? Hello? Uh-huh. Wait. What? I'm sorry, Mr. Decker. I think I'm losing you. [Shedder whirring] Hello? Hello? Yeah. Hold on one second. I don't know. Hold on one second.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Do you really have to do that right now?

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Yes I do. I should have done it weeks ago actually.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Mr. Decker, I'm sorry about that. What were you... Can you hold on one second? Yeah, just one second. Thanks. [Power off, silence] Hello? That's it. Perfect. So what I was saying... [Dialing tone] Hello? Thanks, Dwight.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Retaliation. Tit for tit.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: That is not the expression.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Well, it should be.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: This is my biggest sale of the year. They love me over there for some reason. I'm not really sure why but I make one call over there every year, just to renew their account, and that one call ends up being 25% of my commission for the whole year, so I buy a mini bottle of champagne, celebrate a little. And this year I'm pushing recycled paper on them for one percent more. I know. I'm getting cocky. Right?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Solitaire?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Yeah, Freecell.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Six on seven.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: I know. I saw that.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: So then, why didn't you do it?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: I'm saving that 'cause I like it when the cards go T-ts-ts-tch-tch-tch.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Who doesn't love that?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Hey, Oscar! How are you doing, man?

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: All right.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Did you have a good weekend going there?

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: It was fine.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Oh yeah, I bet it was fun. [to Mr. Brown] Oh, hey! This is Oscar--

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: Martinez.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Right. See? I don't even know, first-name basis!

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Great. We're all set.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Oh hey, well, diversity, everybody, let's do it. Oscar works in... here. Jim, could you wrap it up, please?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Yeah, uh, Mr. Decker, please.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: It's diversity day, Jim. I wish every day was diversity day.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: You know what? I'm actually going to have to call you back. Thank you. Sorry about that.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Great.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Come on people, let's get 'em in. Get in the cards! Get in the cards!

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Thank you. Thank you very much. OK. Thanks for filling these out and I promise this'll be quick. At Diversity Today, our philosophy is about honesty and positive expectations. We believe that 99% of the problems in the workplace arise simply out of ignorance.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: You know what? This is a color-free-zone here. Stanley, I don't look at you as another race.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Uh, see this is what I'm talking about. We don't have to pretend we're color-blind.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Exactly, were not...

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: That's fighting ignorance with more ignorance.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: With tolerance.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: No. With more ignorance.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Ignorance.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Right. Exactly. Uh, instead, we need to celebrate our diversity.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Let's celebrate.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Right. OK.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Celebrate good times. Come on! Let's celebrate diversity. Right?

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Yes, exactly. Now here's what we're going to do. I've noticed that...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: You know what? Here's what we're going to do. Why don't we go around and everybody... everybody say a race that you are attracted to sexually. I will go last. Go.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: I have two. White and Indian.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Actually, I'd prefer not to start that way. Michael, I would love to have your permission to run this session. Can I have your permission?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yes.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Thank you very much. And it would also help me if you were seated.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Thank you. OK. Now, at the start of the session, I had you all write down an incident that you found offensive in the workplace. Now, what I'm going to do is choose one and we're going to act it out.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: A few of the ground rules?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Hey, hey why don't you run it by me and I'll run it by him.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: OK, can we steer away from gay people?

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Um...

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: I'm sorry. It's an orientation. It's not a race. Plus a lot of other races are intolerant of gays, so...paradox.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Well, we only have an hour.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: I figured it would save time.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK. Why don't we just defer to Mr...

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Mr. Brown.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Ah. Oh, right! OK. First test. I will not call you that.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Well, it's my name. It's not a test. OK? Um, so looking through the cards, I've noticed that many of you wrote down the same incident, which is ironic, because it's the exact incident I was brought in here to respond to. Now, how many of you are familiar with the Chris Rock routine? Very good. OK.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: How come Chris Rock can do a routine and everybody finds it hilarious and ground-breaking and then I go and do the exact same routine, same comedic timing, and people file a complaint to Corporate? Is it because I'm white and Chris is black?

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: So we're going to reenact this with a more positive outcome.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: I will play the Chris Rock guy. I would like to see someone else pull this off.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Well, let's have someone who wasn't involved in the reenactment.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK, I will play guy listening.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Great. Guy listening. Ok, anyone else remember?

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: I remember.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Great. You're the Chris Rock guy and you're guy listening.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Kevin is a great guy. He's a great accountant. He is not much of an entertainer.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: Basically, there are two types of black people and black people are actually more racist because they hate the other type of black people. Every time the one type wants to have a good time, then the other type comes in and makes a real mess.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. He's ruin... He's butchering it. Could you just let me... [As Chris Rock] Every time... Every time black people want to have a good time, some ignant ass... [Bleep] I take care of my kid!

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Wait a second.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [Bleep] They always want credit for something they supPOSED to do!

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Stop it!

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [As Chris Rock] What you want a cookie?

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Now, this is a simple acronym. HERO. Uh, at Diversity Today, we believe it is very easy to be a HERO. All you need are honesty, empathy, respect and open-mindedness.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Excuse me, I'm sorry, but that's not all it takes to be a hero.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Oh, great. Well, what is a hero to you?

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: A hero kills people, people that wish him harm.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: OK.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: A hero is part-human and part-supernatural. A hero is born out of a childhood trauma, or out of a disaster that must be avenged.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Ok, you're thinking of a superhero.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: We all have a hero in our heart.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Now, I need you to take these forms. This kind of expresses the joint experience we had today. And I need you to look 'em over and sign them as kind of a group pledge.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [Clears throat] I don't think I can sign this.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: I can't leave until you do.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Well, OK, it says here that I learned something and I knew all this stuff already, so... I know, I could sign something that says that I taught something, or that I helped you teach something, so... Pam! Where is she? Pam, could we change something on this?

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Michael, can I talk to you candidly?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Sure.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: We both know that I'm here because of the comments you made.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Here's the thing. This office, I think this is very advanced in terms of... racial awareness and it's probably more advanced than you're used to. That's probably throwing you off a little bit.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Um, it's not throwing me. I need your signature.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK, well I know. You told me that several times.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Yes, but you're not listening to me. Yours is the only signature I need.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Those are my instructions from the Corporate offices to put you through this seminar for the comments that you made. The reason I made copies for everyone was so you wouldn't be embarrassed.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Well, here I am thinking that you actually cared about diversity training. And you don't.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Don't worry about dating.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: I won't.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: OK. Thank you.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yeah, yeah.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: "I regret my actions. I regret offending my coworkers. I pledge to bring my best spirit of honesty, empathy, respect and open-mindedness..." Open-mindedness, is that even a word? "...into the workplace. In this way, I can truly be a hero. Signed, Daffy Duck." [Laughing] He's going to lose it when he reads that.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Yeah, hi. Is Mr. Decker around? Oh, well, could you just have him call me after lunch? Thank you.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: "I pledge to always keep an open mind and an open heart." I do believe... in that part of the pledge I that just read. But a pledge? Come on. I mean who are we, the Girl Scouts? No. Look... the guy, "Mr. Brown," he got us halfway there. He got us talking. Well, no. I got us talking. He got us nothing. He insulted us and he abandoned us. You call that diversity training? I don't. Were there any connections between any of us? Did anyone look each other in the eye? Was there any emotion going on? No. Where was the heart? I didn't see any heart. Where was my Oprah moment? OK, get as much done as you can before lunch because, afterward, I'm going to have you all in tears.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: All right? Everybody pretty? Come on. Here we go. It's time. Let's do some good.

Quote.Speaker: Toby
Quote.Text: Hey, we're not all going to sit in a circle Indian style are we? [Laughing]

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Get out.

Quote.Speaker: Toby
Quote.Text: I'm sorry.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: No, this is not a joke. OK? That was offensive and lame. So double offensive. This is an environment of welcoming and you should just get the hell out of here. OK, let's go. Let's do it. Come on. Let's have some fun, everybody. Here we go. Take a seat. Cop a squat. And um... thanks for coming in. Um... Diversity... is the cornerstone of progress as I've always said. But don't take my word for it. Let's take a look at the tape.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [on the tape] Hi. I'm Michael Scott. I'm in charge of Dunder Mifflin Paper Products here in Scranton, Pennsylvania but I'm also the founder of Diversity Tomorrow, because today is almost over. Abraham Lincoln once said that, "If you're a racist, I will attack you with the North." And those are the principles that I carry with me in the workplace.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK. Questions? Comments? Anybody? Jim?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Uh, is that it?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yes. I only had an hour to put it together but I'm going to add on to it later on.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: It was kind of hard to hear.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Uh, yes. That probably had something to do with the camera work. Anybody else? Um...

Quote.Speaker: Kelly
Quote.Text: I have a customer meeting.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yeah, well, if you leave we'll only have two left. Yes. Enjoy. Absolutely. Namaste. Ok, well since I am leading this, let's get down to business and why don't I just kind of introduce myself, OK? Um. I am Michael and I am part English, Irish, German and Scottish. Sort of a virtual United Nations. But what some of you might not know is that I am also part Native American Indian.

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: What part Native American?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Two fifteenths.

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: Two fifteenths, that fraction doesn't make any sense.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Well, you know what, it's kind of hard for me to talk about it. Their suffering. So who else? Let's get this popping. Come on. Who's going? Who's going? Let's go here. Oscar, right here. You're on.

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: OK, Michael, um... Both my parents were born in Mexico.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Oh, yeah...

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: And, uh, they moved to the United Sates a year before I was born. So I grew up in the United States.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Wow.

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: My parents were Mexican.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Wow. That is... That is a great story. That's the American Dream right there, right?

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: Thank... Yeah...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Um, let me ask you, is there a term besides Mexican that you prefer? Something less offensive?

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: Mexican isn't offensive.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Well, it has certain connotations.

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: Like what?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Like... I don't... I don't know.

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: What connotations, Michael? You meant something.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: No. Now, remember that honesty...

Quote.Speaker: Oscar
Quote.Text: I'm just curious.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: ...empathy, respect... [Phone ringing] Jim! Jim!

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Hello? Hello?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: I have something here. I want you to take a card. Put it on your fore... Don't look at the card. I want you to take the card and put it on your forehead and... Take a card, take a card, any card. Um... And I want you to treat other people like the race that is on their forehead. OK? So everybody has a different race. Nobody knows what their race is, so... I want you to really go for it, cause this is real. You know, this isn't just an exercise. This is real life. And... I have a dream that you will really let the sparks fly. Get 'er done.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Why? Because Martin Luther King is a hero of mine. There's this great Chris Rock bit about how streets named after Martin Luther King tend to be more violent. I'm not going to do it but it's...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Oh this is a good one.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Um, hi. How are you?

Quote.Speaker: Stanley
Quote.Text: Fine. How are you?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Great.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Push it.

Quote.Speaker: Stanley
Quote.Text: I admire your culture's success in America.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Thank you.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Good. Bom bom bom-bom bom. Come on Olympics of Suffering right here. Slavery versus the Holocaust. Come on.

Quote.Speaker: Stanley
Quote.Text: Who am I supposed to be?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: No, that was inadvertent. We didn't actually plan that.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Lots of cultures eat rice, doesn't help me.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Um... Shalom. I'd like to apply for a loan.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: That's nice, Dwight.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: OK, do me. Something stereotypical so I can get it really quick.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: OK, I like your food.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Outback steakhouse. [Australian accent] I'm Australian, mate!

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Pam, come on. "I like your food." Come on stir the pot. Stir the melting pot, Pam! Let's do it. Let's get ugly. Let's get real.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: OK. If I have to do this, based on stereotypes that are totally untrue, that I do not agree with, you would maybe not be a very good driver.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Oh, man, am I a woman?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: You'll notice I didn't have anybody be an Arab. I thought that would be too explosive. No pun intended. But I just though. "Too soon for Arabs." Maybe next year. Um... You know, the ball's in their court.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: What are you watching?

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: Chappelle's Show.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Really?

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: I downloaded it on her computer. I hope she doesn't mind. She just had a lot of extra space.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: No way. I think she likes this stuff.

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: Great. She's cute, huh?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Yeah, you know, she's engaged, but...

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: Oh, no, the girl in the... sketch.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Oh, yeah. She's hot.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: Hey.

Quote.Speaker: Angela
Quote.Text: Hey.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: You wanna go to the beach?

Quote.Speaker: Angela
Quote.Text: Sure.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: You wanna get high?

Quote.Speaker: Angela
Quote.Text: No.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: I think you do, mon.

Quote.Speaker: Angela
Quote.Text: Stop...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: OK. All right. No. It's good. You just need to push it. You need to go a little bit further. All right. OK.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [Voice raised, Indian accent] Kelly, how are you?

Quote.Speaker: Kelly
Quote.Text: I just had the longest meeting.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Oh! Welcome to my convenience store. Would you like some googi googi? I have some very delicious googi, googi, only 99 cents plus tax. Try my googi, googi. [Lowering voice] Try my googi, googi. [High-pitched voice] Try my googi, googi. Try my... [slap!]

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [trying not to cry] All right! All right! Yes! That was great, she gets it! Now she knows what it's like to be a minority.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: [on the phone] Mr. Decker, we didn't lose your sale today, did we? Excellent. OK. Let me just get your... what's that? No, we didn't close last time. I just need your... Oh. W-What code were you given? Oh, OK. That's actually another salesman here. I can redo it if you want to do that. Oh, he gave you a discount? No, I don't blame you.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: I just hated it when that guy was in here. Mr. Brown, if that was his real name. I mean, he had never met any of us before, and here he was telling us how to do our thing. I just wanted... I just wanted to do it our way. You know? On our own. Man I should have gotten some food.

Quote.Speaker: Kevin
Quote.Text: [Italian accent]Maybe some spagh-etti.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Okay, Kevin. You can take that off that thing, OK? That would really, really have shown him up, wouldn't it? If I'd brought in some burritos or some colored greens. Or some pad Thai. I love pad Thai.

Quote.Speaker: Stanley
Quote.Text: It's collard greens.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: What?

Quote.Speaker: Stanley
Quote.Text: It's collard greens.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: That doesn't really make sense. Because you don't call them collared people, that's offensive. Hmmm... OK, well, it's after five. So... Thank you very much. Buena vista Oscar. Thank you. Good job. Oh, my man. Thank you Brazil. Nice.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: [Pam is asleep, resting her head on Jim's shoulder] Um... Hey.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: [stirs] Mmmm.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Hey.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Oh.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: We can go.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Sorry.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: That's fine.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Uh... Not a bad day.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Thanks for filling these out. I promise this will be quick. We only have about an hour.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yeah. I would like to see us erase 100 years of racism in an hour.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Does this company have 100 years to erase?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: No, the country.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Oh right, more like 200 years.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yeah, more like a 1,000.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Okay, um. Uh, I'll try to make this quick.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: I am a salesman, okay. And I don't think we should be doing this during prime sales hours. If you can prove to me that diversity is going to help my sales, I'll go elephant running with James Earl Jones. I really will, but not on spec.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: HERO, at Diversity Today, we believe it is very easy to be a HERO. All you need are honesty, empathy, respect and open-mindedness.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: I just think that HERO? It's cute, but it's... It's empty, you know? It's easy. Dwight, you know what, I came up with some terms of my own. Could you put these on the board? The first one is Inclusion, New Attitudes, Color-blind...

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Oh, nice.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Expectations....

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Good.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Thank you. Sharing...

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Great.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: And tolerance.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Beautiful.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Um, that spells incest.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Oh, my sorry. That is not appropriate.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Well, it's not ideal but you have to give me some credit 'cause I made it into a word.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Yeah, but it's not appropriate. This is not helpful as a memory aid.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: I will give you a number of reasons why it is, actually. Okay, first, incest is bad. Racism is bad. No brainer, right? Two, incest. We're all a family, right? We're all brothers and sisters. Racial message? Um? Number three, and this is a fact. The states where they have a lot of racism are the states where they have a lot of incest. Okay? And finally...

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Okay, Michael, I just...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: No, no, no, no, wait. Final one, final one this is important. The more we can encourage interracial dating as a society the further away we get from incest, literally.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: It would've been just as easy for him to spell insect. Of course, that wouldn't have made any sense either.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Does anyone have anything else at all? Anyone besides Michael?

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: I have something.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: Yes, please.

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: Um, well I grew up here in Scranton and when I was a kid the guy who lived next door was a former baseball player, who actually played pro ball before the leagues were integrated. And he had the most incredible stories about...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Okay. I'm sorry, I'm sorry this guy's a temp and I should've told you that.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: No, no, no, no. An outsider's perspective would probably be pretty helpful.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yeah, but no, seriously. Uh, you know, he's not a member of the full staff so, uh, Ryan you wanna just step outside?

Quote.Speaker: Ryan
Quote.Text: What do you want me to do?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Well, maybe you should go down to the parking lot. You know what. Yes, go down to the parking lot and check to se if any of our guests have parked in the handicapped spots. Cool? 'Cause the handicaps get a raw deal. Oh, you know what. That ties right into New Attitudes. New attitudes about handicap people. Very important.

Quote.Speaker: Mr. Brown
Quote.Text: I'm sorry, Michael. We're actually out of time.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Yeah, um, there's good things about Michael. He uh, uh... Yeah, definitely. Um...

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: "In this way, I can truly be a hero. Signed, Daffy Duck."

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [laughing] He's going to lose it when he reads that. Doh! Hogan! Not again, Hogan! Get Col. Burkhalter on the phone! [laughing] I'm kind of a Hogan around here. And kind of, Jan is kind of Col. Burkhalter, then Dwight is Schultz. But, it's... Oh, God. We have fun. We have fun. 'Cause he's gonna be pissed. [making voice] No doubt about it.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: What you doing?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Freecell.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Solitaire is a one-player game. It can't have two players.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Well, I mean.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: What's your win rate?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: Seventy-six percent. What's yours?

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: You're not allowed to play two-player. You need to start over.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: You're doing fine.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Are we going? [Dwight puts four fingers in front of the camera to start a countdown] Don't do that. Just say action when we're ready.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Dunder Mifflin, Michael Scott, Diversity Tomorrow, take four. And action.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [mumbling] Should I... turn, no. Do it again.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Diversity Tomorrow, take five. Action.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Hi. I'm Michael Scott. I'm in charge of Dunder Mifflin Paper Products here in Scranton, Pennsylvania but I'm also the founder of Diversity Tomorrow, because today is almost over. Abraham Lincoln once said that, "If you're a racist, I will attack you with the North." And those are the principles... Damn it. Okay, sorry. Don't laugh; please don't laugh this time Dwight. You're... it's, it's bugging me. Let me give myself a countdown, ready? Three, two, one.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Take six.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Just let me do it! God! Three, two, one. Hi. I'm Michael Scott. I'm in charge of Dunder Mifflin Paper Products here in Scranton... Keep the camera steady please! People are gonna get sea sick watching this. Ready? Three, two, one.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Action.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Don't. Please don't say anything. [sighs] Oh, God.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: And action... Lights, camera, action. Whenever you're ready.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Could I count myself down please, Dwight. Three, two, one. Hi. I'm Michael Scott. I'm in charge of Dunder Mifflin Paper Products here in Scranton, Pennsylvania but I'm also the founder of Diversity Tomorrow, because today is almost over. Abraham Lincoln once said that, "If you're a racist, I will attack you with the North." And those are the principles that I carry with me in the workplace.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Cut.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: [wandering around the room during his diversity exercise] I want you to push it. I want you to push 'cause breakthroughs are right around the corner. Something's going to pop here. Something's going to pop between a party. Feel what it's like to be in someone else's skin. What does it feel like to be a different race? It feels pretty bad doesn't it. So let that come out.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Yeah, I marched on Washington back in the day. I went to the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial, U.S. Mint, congressman talked to our class. It was pretty cool.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Talk like you're talking to that race. I have a feeling that this could get kind of volatile. So keep it going. [camera shows Devon sitting outside with West Nile]

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Um, what's going on here?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: People treat us like the race on our forehead. And then we guess what race we are.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Ah, good. Good luck. Doing good. [goes to the index cards and writes another race down]

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Oh, man, am I a woman?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Yes, yes.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: God!

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: How embarrassing is it? That's not fair. Here...

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: It's not fair.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Try this. [takes Dwight's 'Asian' race and switches it with the one he wrote]

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Thank you. Thank you very much.

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Go get 'em.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Good. [clears throat] So, am I a hunter gather culture?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: No.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Do I live near a harbor or an ocean?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: No.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: No, I'm an inland. Am I a mountainous?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: No.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Am I nomadic?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: No.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: Okay, okay, okay, okay. I think I got this. Um, I am treated in a foreign way with a great deal of prejudice. Am I one of those tribes in Africa? The piggies, or whatever?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: No.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: No. But I am, I am human, right? [Pam hesitates]

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: [Dwight's new race is 'Dwight'] I could be French.

Quote.Speaker: Dwight
Quote.Text: [takes his 'Dwight' race off his forehead] Damn it, Jim! That's not funny, Jim!

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Oh, okay. Here we go, breakthrough radar. What happened? What happened here?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: It didn't have anything to do with race.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Okay, all right. Let's keep on track. Keep on point. Let's do it.

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: One time we had an ethnic festival in Scranton. One time.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: Try my googi, googi. [Lowering voice] Try my googi, googi. [High-pitched voice] Try my googi, googi. Try my... [Kelly slaps Michael] All right! All right! Yes! That was great, she gets it! Kelly thank you. [claps] She's not here, but she gets it. That's what we have been looking for. The whole time. [trying not to cry] Oh, man. This is what I thrive on. You know? It's like Don Rickles on acid, man. Right?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: Um, why did she slap Martin Luther King?

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: What, huh?

Quote.Speaker: Pam
Quote.Text: What card was she?

Quote.Speaker: Jim
Quote.Text: I think she wasn't wearing a card.

Quote.Speaker: Michael
Quote.Text: It's good. This is good. We got it happening now. All right? Let's keep it rolling. Let's round it up.
